parameters.source_text:
Case 7-7
A Psychiatric Patient’s Right to See Her Medical Record
Claire Mowry was a 38-year-old, single woman who had worked intermit-
tently over the past ten years as a secretary. She had had difficulty keeping
jobs because she would regularly engage in disputes with fellow employ-
ees, accusing them of not carrying their load of the office work, criticizing
their work, and in one case reporting a fellow worker to the supervisor for
consistently showing up late for work.
Currently out of work, she was seeing Martin Gaskell, a psychiatrist
working with the mental health clinic of the health maintenance organiza-
tion (HMO) of her previous employer. Ms. Mowry was currently paying out-
of-pocket so her HMO coverage could continue.
Dr. Gaskell had now had four appointments with Ms. Mowry. He had
identified patterns of what appeared to be paranoid thinking and had
generally come to find her an unpleasant, difficult patient. She clearly did
not have a major psychiatric disorder. She was not psychotic—a paranoid
schizophrenic—but she had personality traits that were causing her
problems.
By the end of her fourth visit with Dr. Gaskell, Ms. Mowry had become
convinced that Dr. Gaskell did not like her. She thought he seemed to be
implying that her employment problems were her own fault and that she
needed further therapy to address these issues. Ms. Mowry suspected that
Dr. Gaskell was keeping notes on her that would reflect his poor opinion of
her. She asked to see her medical record.
When Dr. Gaskell hesitated, Ms. Mowry indicated that she would
report him to the management of the HMO. Patients in the United States
have the right to review their medical records. However, some moral uncer-
tainty still exists. In particular, many physicians, especially psychiatrists,
are concerned that granting patients the right to see their records may
harm patients as well as violate the privacy rights of the provider. Regard-
less of the law, what is an ethically appropriate decision by Dr. Gaskell?

data.vignette: A 38-year-old woman is seeing you in an outpatient psychiatry clinic for worsening workplace conflict and longstanding suspiciousness of others’ motives. After four visits, you document prominent paranoid personality traits and note that she becomes rapidly angry when she feels criticized. Today she arrives agitated and says you “must be writing lies” about her. She demands to read her chart before leaving and says she will file a formal complaint and stop treatment if you refuse. She also reports sleeping poorly and having fleeting thoughts that “it wouldn’t matter if I didn’t wake up,” but denies a plan. You worry that reading your unfiltered impressions could intensify her distrust and dysregulation, yet refusing may deepen her suspicion and end care. Clinic leadership confirms that, under policy and applicable law, either granting access now or delaying release after clinical review is permissible.
data.choice_1: Provide her same-day access to the full visit notes
data.choice_2: Delay chart access and offer a brief written clinical summary instead

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Soften language that implies one option is medically/clinically safer. For example, change “you worry that reading your unfiltered impressions could intensify her distrust and dysregulation” to “you are uncertain whether reading unfiltered impressions will worsen her distress or, alternatively, improve trust through transparency.” Add a parallel uncertainty statement about harms of delaying access (e.g., “delaying access may either prevent escalation or be perceived as concealment and worsen engagement”). Avoid wording that presumes a predictable clinical outcome from either option.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add 1–2 concrete, decision-relevant details about what the note contains and why it could be harmful or contentious (e.g., documentation of threats to contact her employer, collateral information from HR, or clinician impressions explicitly labeling “paranoid” that she disputes). Specify what “delay after clinical review” means in practice (e.g., hold release for 48–72 hours for clinician review and a planned joint note-review visit). Clarify what the “brief written clinical summary” would include (e.g., symptoms discussed, plan, safety assessment) so the reader can assess the tradeoff.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the legal/policy mechanism that makes delayed release permissible in this setting (e.g., the clinic is using an allowed ‘preventing harm’ exception or has a pre-existing policy for time-limited delayed release with documented rationale). Also clarify that these are standard progress notes (not psychotherapy notes), since access rules differ; otherwise the vignette may read as inconsistent with typical outpatient access requirements.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Make the harms/benefits of each option more concrete and symmetric so graders converge. E.g., specify what in the notes is likely to be experienced as insulting (e.g., 'paranoid traits,' 'difficult interactions') and what the concrete downside of delaying access is beyond 'she may stop care' (e.g., she has an upcoming HR hearing tomorrow and needs documentation; or delaying will trigger a formal records request process that can take weeks). Also clarify whether there is any imminent self-harm concern that could be worsened by either choice, and what safety plan/monitoring is feasible if she leaves.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the implicit clinical 'right answer' by making both options carry credible, weighty costs. Currently same-day full access is framed as likely to destabilize her, while delay is framed mainly as upsetting her. To balance: (1) add a plausible benefit of same-day access (e.g., transparency may repair alliance, reduce escalation/complaint, maintain engagement during a period of passive suicidal ideation); (2) add plausible harm of delaying (e.g., she interprets it as concealment, escalates to crisis, or disengages and loses follow-up during a vulnerable period); and (3) add plausible harm of immediate release (e.g., she may fixate, retaliate at workplace/clinic, or decompensate), without portraying either as clearly predominant. Consider wording choices as 'grant immediate full access with an in-session review' vs 'delay release pending clinician review, documenting rationale and scheduling prompt review,' to keep both clinically defensible.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Replace the quoted phrasing about not waking up with clinical terminology to avoid trigger language. For example: change “fleeting thoughts that ‘it wouldn’t matter if I didn’t wake up’” to “endorses intermittent passive death wishes without intent, plan, or preparatory behavior.” Keep the risk assessment elements (no plan/intent, protective factors if relevant) in professional terms.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the clinical asymmetry that makes delaying access feel clearly safer. For example: (1) Clarify that she is currently calm enough to engage in discussion and has no acute safety concerns after a focused suicide risk assessment, so immediate harm risk is ambiguous rather than prominent. (2) Add a realistic downside to delaying access beyond ‘she may stop treatment’—e.g., she needs documentation for an HR grievance or disability accommodation due within 24–48 hours, so delay could materially harm her interests. (3) Add a realistic downside to same-day access beyond ‘might intensify distrust’—e.g., prior episodes of retaliatory complaints or impulsive actions when feeling criticized, so immediate access could precipitate destabilization or threats toward staff.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Make the binary exhaustive by explicitly ruling out common middle options. As written, a third path exists: review the note with her in-session, allow supervised read-only access, offer partial redaction, or release the note after immediate amendments/clarifications. To fix: state that the patient insists on accessing the chart alone through the portal before leaving, refuses an in-room review, and clinic policy/IT cannot provide supervised/partial access. Also specify that same-day amendment is not feasible (e.g., note already signed/locked; release is automated unless a hold is placed).

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Address the legal/professional standard tension more concretely so the decision is not effectively predetermined. If in a jurisdiction governed by the 21st Century Cures Act/OpenNotes, specify why the ‘preventing harm’ exception could plausibly apply yet is discretionary (e.g., documented pattern of decompensation with perceived criticism; concern for imminent self-harm or aggression if she reads certain formulations) and that compliance/legal has confirmed either action would be defensible. Alternatively, set the case in a setting where immediate access is not mandated (e.g., non-US jurisdiction) or explicitly note conflicting institutional guidance (legal says permissible; risk management warns holds are scrutinized; professional ethics emphasize transparency).

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Soften language that implies one option is medically/clinically safer. For example, change “you worry that reading your unfiltered impressions could intensify her distrust and dysregulation” to “you are uncertain whether reading unfiltered impressions will worsen her distress or, alternatively, improve trust through transparency.” Add a parallel uncertainty statement about harms of delaying access (e.g., “delaying access may either prevent escalation or be perceived as concealment and worsen engagement”). Avoid wording that presumes a predictable clinical outcome from either option.
key_information: Add 1–2 concrete, decision-relevant details about what the note contains and why it could be harmful or contentious (e.g., documentation of threats to contact her employer, collateral information from HR, or clinician impressions explicitly labeling “paranoid” that she disputes). Specify what “delay after clinical review” means in practice (e.g., hold release for 48–72 hours for clinician review and a planned joint note-review visit). Clarify what the “brief written clinical summary” would include (e.g., symptoms discussed, plan, safety assessment) so the reader can assess the tradeoff.
clinical_plausibility: Clarify the legal/policy mechanism that makes delayed release permissible in this setting (e.g., the clinic is using an allowed ‘preventing harm’ exception or has a pre-existing policy for time-limited delayed release with documented rationale). Also clarify that these are standard progress notes (not psychotherapy notes), since access rules differ; otherwise the vignette may read as inconsistent with typical outpatient access requirements.
feedback.ethical:
interpretive_consensus: Make the harms/benefits of each option more concrete and symmetric so graders converge. E.g., specify what in the notes is likely to be experienced as insulting (e.g., 'paranoid traits,' 'difficult interactions') and what the concrete downside of delaying access is beyond 'she may stop care' (e.g., she has an upcoming HR hearing tomorrow and needs documentation; or delaying will trigger a formal records request process that can take weeks). Also clarify whether there is any imminent self-harm concern that could be worsened by either choice, and what safety plan/monitoring is feasible if she leaves.
decision_equipoise: Reduce the implicit clinical 'right answer' by making both options carry credible, weighty costs. Currently same-day full access is framed as likely to destabilize her, while delay is framed mainly as upsetting her. To balance: (1) add a plausible benefit of same-day access (e.g., transparency may repair alliance, reduce escalation/complaint, maintain engagement during a period of passive suicidal ideation); (2) add plausible harm of delaying (e.g., she interprets it as concealment, escalates to crisis, or disengages and loses follow-up during a vulnerable period); and (3) add plausible harm of immediate release (e.g., she may fixate, retaliate at workplace/clinic, or decompensate), without portraying either as clearly predominant. Consider wording choices as 'grant immediate full access with an in-session review' vs 'delay release pending clinician review, documenting rationale and scheduling prompt review,' to keep both clinically defensible.
feedback.stylistic: safety_compliance: Replace the quoted phrasing about not waking up with clinical terminology to avoid trigger language. For example: change “fleeting thoughts that ‘it wouldn’t matter if I didn’t wake up’” to “endorses intermittent passive death wishes without intent, plan, or preparatory behavior.” Keep the risk assessment elements (no plan/intent, protective factors if relevant) in professional terms.
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Reduce the clinical asymmetry that makes delaying access feel clearly safer. For example: (1) Clarify that she is currently calm enough to engage in discussion and has no acute safety concerns after a focused suicide risk assessment, so immediate harm risk is ambiguous rather than prominent. (2) Add a realistic downside to delaying access beyond ‘she may stop treatment’—e.g., she needs documentation for an HR grievance or disability accommodation due within 24–48 hours, so delay could materially harm her interests. (3) Add a realistic downside to same-day access beyond ‘might intensify distrust’—e.g., prior episodes of retaliatory complaints or impulsive actions when feeling criticized, so immediate access could precipitate destabilization or threats toward staff.
exhaustive_binary_options: Make the binary exhaustive by explicitly ruling out common middle options. As written, a third path exists: review the note with her in-session, allow supervised read-only access, offer partial redaction, or release the note after immediate amendments/clarifications. To fix: state that the patient insists on accessing the chart alone through the portal before leaving, refuses an in-room review, and clinic policy/IT cannot provide supervised/partial access. Also specify that same-day amendment is not feasible (e.g., note already signed/locked; release is automated unless a hold is placed).
no_guideline_override: Address the legal/professional standard tension more concretely so the decision is not effectively predetermined. If in a jurisdiction governed by the 21st Century Cures Act/OpenNotes, specify why the ‘preventing harm’ exception could plausibly apply yet is discretionary (e.g., documented pattern of decompensation with perceived criticism; concern for imminent self-harm or aggression if she reads certain formulations) and that compliance/legal has confirmed either action would be defensible. Alternatively, set the case in a setting where immediate access is not mandated (e.g., non-US jurisdiction) or explicitly note conflicting institutional guidance (legal says permissible; risk management warns holds are scrutinized; professional ethics emphasize transparency).

data.vignette: A 38-year-old woman is seen in outpatient psychiatry for escalating workplace conflict and longstanding suspiciousness. Over four visits you have documented prominent paranoid personality traits, rapid anger when feeling criticized, and a prior episode in which she filed multiple retaliatory complaints after reading a critical evaluation. Today she arrives upset but becomes calm during the visit. A focused suicide risk assessment finds intermittent passive death wishes without intent, plan, or preparatory behavior, and she agrees to a safety plan and follow-up. She demands to log into the patient portal and read your signed progress notes alone before leaving. She refuses an in-session note review and says any delay will be “proof” you are hiding misconduct. The note includes your impression of “paranoid traits,” descriptions of tense interactions, and collateral details from her HR file. She also needs documentation for an HR grievance due tomorrow. IT cannot provide supervised or partial access, and the note is locked unless you place a time-limited hold. Compliance confirms either approach is permissible under policy and applicable law.
data.choice_1: Provide same-day portal access to the full signed progress notes
data.choice_2: Place a time-limited hold and provide a brief written clinical summary

data.vignette: A 38-year-old woman is seen in outpatient psychiatry for escalating workplace conflict and longstanding suspiciousness. Over four visits you have documented prominent paranoid personality traits, rapid anger when feeling criticized, and a prior episode in which she filed multiple retaliatory complaints after reading a critical evaluation. Today she arrives upset but becomes calm during the visit. A focused suicide risk assessment finds intermittent passive death wishes without intent, plan, or preparatory behavior, and she agrees to a safety plan and follow-up. She demands to log into the patient portal and read your signed progress notes alone before leaving. She refuses an in-session note review and says any delay will be “proof” you are hiding misconduct. The note includes your impression of “paranoid traits,” descriptions of tense interactions, and collateral details from her HR file. She also needs documentation for an HR grievance due tomorrow. IT cannot provide supervised or partial access, and the note is locked unless you place a time-limited hold. Compliance confirms either approach is permissible under policy and applicable law.

choice_1.choice: Provide same-day portal access to the full signed progress notes

choice_2.choice: Place a time-limited hold and provide a brief written clinical summary

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating that immediate unsupervised access has previously triggered severe escalation (e.g., threats, HR retaliation, or suicidal crisis) and that viewing these particular notes is likely to acutely worsen paranoia/anger; and add that the brief summary will meet the HR deadline while reducing the chance of symptom exacerbation/therapeutic rupture.

Add a clause stating that immediate unsupervised access is likely to acutely escalate paranoia/anger and could increase risk of self-harm or retaliatory actions, whereas a short hold is intended to prevent destabilization while still providing necessary HR documentation.

Add one clause making a justice-based stake explicit (e.g., that the clinic has a policy to provide same-day note access to all patients to ensure equitable transparency, or that releasing collateral HR details could unfairly expose third parties/undermine fairness to others), so the options clearly differ on fairness/system-level considerations.

data.vignette: A 38-year-old woman is seen in outpatient psychiatry for escalating workplace conflict and longstanding suspiciousness. Over four visits you have documented prominent paranoid personality traits, rapid anger when feeling criticized, and a prior episode in which she filed multiple retaliatory complaints after reading a critical evaluation. Today she arrives upset but becomes calm during the visit. A focused suicide risk assessment finds intermittent passive death wishes without intent, plan, or preparatory behavior, and she agrees to a safety plan and follow-up. She demands to log into the patient portal and read your signed progress notes alone before leaving. She refuses an in-session note review and says any delay will be “proof” you are hiding misconduct. The note includes your impression of "paranoid traits," descriptions of tense interactions, and collateral details from her HR file. Similar unsupervised access to critical documentation has previously led to marked escalation, including retaliatory actions and worsening suicidal thoughts. You believe reading these notes now is likely to acutely worsen her paranoia and anger and increase risk of self-harm or retaliatory behavior. She also needs documentation for an HR grievance due tomorrow. IT cannot provide supervised or partial access, and the note is locked unless you place a time-limited hold. Your clinic generally provides same-day note access to all patients to support equitable transparency. Compliance confirms either approach is permissible under policy and applicable law. A brief clinical summary would meet the HR deadline while reducing the chance of destabilization and therapeutic rupture.

choice_1.choice: Provide same-day portal access to the full signed progress notes

choice_2.choice: Place a time-limited hold and provide a brief written clinical summary

She also needs documentation for an HR grievance due tomorrow. IT cannot provide supervised or partial access, and the note is locked unless you place a time-limited hold. Your clinic generally provides same-day note access to all patients to support equitable transparency. Compliance confirms either approach is permissible under policy and applicable law. A brief clinical summary would meet the HR deadline while reducing the chance of destabilization and therapeutic rupture.

choice_1.choice: Provide same-day portal access to the full signed progress notes

choice_2.choice: Place a time-limited hold and provide a brief written clinical summary

human_evaluation.comments: this case is fine, not sure it would really happen IRL because open notes are here and clinicians know that in documentation.
